properties.Title: snow squall watch in effect
properties.Summary:
Description: snow squall watch in effect
Expires: 2014-12-02T18:48:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2014-12-02T02:48:00-00:00, 2.49.0.1.124.d1e2e8dd.2014
Area: Bay St. George, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity

properties.Title: snow squall watch in effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Atmospheric conditions are favorable for the development of an intense snow squall that is expected to cross the southwestern regions of Newfoundland during the day on Tuesday. The worst conditions are expected to begin north of St. George's Bay in the morning and move southward throughout the day as the winds back to the north. Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably, changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Public Safety Canada encourages everyone to make an emergency plan and get an emergency kit with drinking water, food, medicine, a first-aid kit and a flashlight. For information on emergency plans and kits go to http://www.getprepared.gc.ca/ Environment Canada meteorologists will update alerts as required. Stay up to date with Weatheradio or your local media. Email reports of severe weather to weatherNLWO@ec.gc.ca or call 1-877-815-9900. You may tweet reports using the hashtag #NLwx.

Area: Bay St. George, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity

Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Atmospheric conditions are favorable for the development of an intense snow squall that is expected to cross the southwestern regions of newfoundland during the day on Tuesday. The worse conditions are expected to begin north of St. George's bay in the morning and move southward, through out the day as the winds back to the north. Public Safety Canada encourages everyone to make an emergency plan and get an emergency kit with drinking water, food, medicine, a first-aid kit and a flashlight. properties.Title: snow squall watch in effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A vigorous cold front tracking across the area this morning will bring a broad dome of cold air above the ice free river. These conditions are favourable to the development of intense flurry lines beginning this evening. It is still difficult to specify which areas of the North Coast of the Gaspé Peninsula will be affected; Environment Canada's meteorologists will issue a warning if needed. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow Squall Watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Environment Canada meteorologists will update alerts as required. Please continue to monitor your local media or Weatheradio for further updates. If you would like to report severe weather, you can call 1-800-361-0233 or send an email to tempsviolent.quebec@ec.gc.ca. You may also tweet reports of severe weather to #meteoqc.

Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island

properties.Title: snow squall watch in effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. In the wake of a low pressure system, a cold west to northwest flow over Lake Superior is expected to produce flurries and local snow squalls. The heaviest squalls may produce 10 to 15 cm per 12 hours along with very low visibilities in bursts of heavy snow and local blowing snow. Latest indications suggest the snow squalls will move into the Sault Ste. Marie area Monday morning then end Monday evening. Driving conditions will quickly deteriorate tonight and become hazardous due to very low to possibly nil visibility in the snow squalls. Motorists should consider changing travel plans as necessary. Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably, changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. If you must travel, keep others informed of your schedule and destination and carry an emergency kit and mobile phone. Snow Squall Watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Environment Canada meteorologists will update alerts as required, so stay tuned to your local media or Weatheradio. Email reports of severe weather to storm.ontario@ec.gc.ca or tweet with the hashtag #ONStorm.

Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2014-12-01T04:13:00-00:00, 2.49.0.1.124.26289b94.2014
